content.content: Freda Quently is a 30-year-old female presenting with a 2-week history of a persistent nonproductive cough. The patient reports that the cough is mostly dry and does not produce any sputum. There is no associated fever, chills, chest pain, or shortness of contenteath. The patient denies any recent upper respiratory infections, exposure to sick contacts, or travel history. She reports occasional throat irritation but no significant pain. She has tried over-the-counter cough suppressants with minimal relief.
No significant medical history, No known allergies
Never smoker, Occasional alcohol use, Works as a Software engineer

General: No fever, chills, or weight loss. Respiratory: Dry cough, no shortness of contenteath, wheezing, or chest pain. Cardiovascular: No palpitations or chest pain. Gastrointestinal: No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. ENT: Throat irritation, no sore throat, nasal congestion, or ear pain. Other: No recent travel or sick contacts.

Vital Signs: Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg Heart Rate: 76 bpm Respiratory Rate: 16 contenteaths per minute Temperature: 98.6°F Oxygen Saturation: 98% on room air General: Alert and in no acute distress. HEENT: Throat mildly erythematous, no tonsillar exudate, nasal passages clear. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezing, rales, or rhonchi. Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs or gallops. Skin: No rashes or lesions. Extremities: No edema, cyanosis, or clubbing.
Chronic nonproductive cough, likely post-viral or related to throat irritation. Differential diagnosis includes allergic rhinitis, GERD, or asthma.

Medications: Prescribe a short course of a non-sedating antihistamine (e.g., cetirizine 10 mg daily). Consider trial of a proton pump inhibitor if symptoms persist (e.g., omeprazole 20 mg daily). Diagnostics: Recommend chest X-ray if cough persists beyond another 2 weeks or if new symptoms develop. Follow-Up: Follow up with primary care physician in 2 weeks or return to urgent care if symptoms worsen or new symptoms appear. Patient Education: Advise on hydration and use of throat lozenges to manage throat irritation. Avoid known allergens and irritants. Signature: Dr. Emily Thompson Urgent Care Physician QuickCare Urgent Center, 123 Main Street, Anytown, USA 12345 03/24/2024

Freda QuentlyMichaela Johnson is a 30-year-old female returning with a persistent nonproductive cough, now ongoing for 8 weeks. The patient states that the cough remains mostly dry, with no sputum production. She reports that she saw an urgent care 6 weeks ago provided minimal relief with the prescribed antihistamines. There have been no new symptoms such as fever, chills, chest pain, or shortness of contenteath. She notes some mild throat irritation and occasional hoarseness. No recent upper respiratory infections, sick contacts, or travel history. She denies any heartburn or reflux symptoms.
No significant medical history, No known allergies
Never smoker, Occasional alcohol use, Works as a Software engineer

General: No fever, chills, or weight loss. Respiratory: Persistent dry cough, no shortness of contenteath, wheezing, or chest pain. Cardiovascular: No palpitations or chest pain. Gastrointestinal: No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. ENT: Throat irritation, occasional hoarseness, no sore throat or nasal congestion. Other: No recent travel or sick contacts.

Vital Signs: Blood Pressure: 118/78 mmHg Heart Rate: 74 bpm Respiratory Rate: 16 contenteaths per minute Temperature: 98.4°F Oxygen Saturation: 98% on room air General: Alert and in no acute distress. HEENT: Throat mildly erythematous, no tonsillar exudate, nasal passages clear, mild hoarseness noted. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezing, rales, or rhonchi. Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs or gallops. Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no hepatosplenomegaly. Skin: No rashes or lesions. Extremities: No edema, cyanosis, or clubbing.
Persistent chronic nonproductive cough. Differential diagnosis includes post-viral cough, allergic rhinitis, GERD, asthma, or less likely an underlying infectious or inflammatory condition.

Medications: Discontinue cetirizine. Prescribe a trial of a proton pump inhibitor (omeprazole 20 mg daily) for possible GERD-related cough. Diagnostics: Order a chest X-ray to rule out any underlying pulmonary pathology. Consider referral to a pulmonologist if no improvement with the current treatment plan or if the chest X-ray is abnormal. Follow-Up: Follow up with primary care physician or return to urgent care in 2 weeks to reassess symptoms and review chest X-ray results. Patient Education: Encourage hydration and use of throat lozenges to manage throat irritation. Advise on lifestyle modifications such as avoiding spicy foods and elevating the head of the bed if GERD is suspected. Signature: Dr. Mark Davis Urgent Care Physician Express Health Clinic, 456 Oak Avenue Anytown, USA 67890 05/07/2024

tr.td: Visit for chronic cough with associated symptoms

content.content: Chronic cough, fever, chills, hoarseness, and difficulty swallowing.

Freda Quently is a 30-year-old female presenting with a persistent daily cough that has been ongoing for “awhile”. She says she’s tried a few different medications but doesn’t know what they were. The cough is severe enough to wake her from sleep. Additionally, she has experienced intermittent fevers and chills. Over the past week, she has noticed hoarseness in her voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient denies any recent upper respiratory infections, exposure to sick contacts, or travel history. She reports no significant medical history and is not currently on any medications.
Never smoker, Occasional alcohol use, Works as a teacher

General: Reports intermittent fever and chills, no recent weight loss. Respiratory: Persistent, severe cough, no shortness of contenteath, no wheezing. Cardiovascular: No chest pain, no palpitations. Gastrointestinal: Difficulty swallowing, no nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. ENT: Hoarseness, difficulty swallowing, no sore throat or nasal congestion. Other: No recent travel or sick contacts.

Vital Signs: Blood Pressure: 118/76 mmHg Heart Rate: 82 bpm Respiratory Rate: 18 contenteaths per minute Temperature: 99.8°F Oxygen Saturation: 97% on room air General: Alert, in mild distress due to cough. HEENT: Throat mildly erythematous, no tonsillar exudate, mild hoarseness noted. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezing, rales, or rhonchi. Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs or gallops. Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no hepatosplenomegaly. Skin: No rashes or lesions. Extremities: No edema, cyanosis, or clubbing.

Persistent chronic cough with associated fever, chills, hoarseness, and difficulty swallowing. Differential diagnosis includes upper respiratory tract infection, laryngopharyngeal reflux, infectious laryngitis, or possible underlying pulmonary condition.

Medications: Prescribe a short course of oral corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) to reduce inflammation. Prescribe a proton pump inhibitor (e.g., omeprazole 20 mg daily) if reflux is suspected. Diagnostics: Order a chest X-ray to evaluate for any underlying pulmonary pathology. Recommend a throat swab and culture to rule out bacterial infection. Consider referral to an otolaryngologist (ENT) for further evaluation if symptoms persist or worsen. Follow-Up: Follow up in 1 week or sooner if symptoms worsen. Return to urgent care or see primary care physician for chest X-ray results and further management. Patient Education: Encourage hydration and use of throat lozenges to manage throat irritation. Advise on lifestyle modifications such as avoiding spicy foods and elevating the head of the bed if reflux is suspected. Discuss signs and symptoms that should prompt immediate return to urgent care, such as worsening fever, difficulty contenteathing, or severe throat pain. Signature: Dr. Laura Green Urgent Care Physician Priority Medical Urgent Clinic, 101 Elm Street, Greenfield, USA 9876506/26/2024
